Authors:
Yunpeng Zhao, Weiwei Ma, Qiongyan Dai, Zhechen Qi, Pan Li,
Kenneth M. Cameron, Jenny Qiu-Yun Xiang, Chengxin Fu
Title:
Species delineation, phylogenetic relationship, and
biogeographic divergence of Smilax hispida group with eastern
Asian-North American disjuction
Abstract:
The origin of floristic disjunction between eastern Asia
and North America has been well-addressed using a phylogeny-based
historical biogeographic approach over the past two decades. However,
subsequent diversification and evolution of the disjunct taxa after
intercontinental divergence have been scarcely examined. Here, we
conduct a large-scale, inter-continental, phylogeographic investigation
on the Smilax hispida species group which is widely distributed in
eastern Asia and North America and taxonomically controversial.
Phylogenetic analyses and GSI indices based on seven chloroplast and
nuclear sequences strongly support delineation of previously recognized
six species within the clade and their phylogenetic relationships.
Biogeographic analysis and divergence time dating suggested a Central
and/or North American origin of the group crown lineage with a
subsequent dispersal into eastern Asia via the Bering land bridge or
long-distance dispersal at 11.21 mya. The two Mexican/Central American
species, S. jalapensis and S. moranensis, represent consequences of two
biogeographic events. The spatial pattern of genetic divergence within
Asia indicated that the origins of S. scobinicaulis and S. sieboldii
were associated with allopatric divergence of the ancestral population.
NST/GST tests and AMOVA further indicated that infraspecific genetic
divergence in the two Asian species are greater than in eastern American
species S. hispida, and the divergence is largely allopatric. Our
results suggest principal effects of geographical barriers on population
differentiation, and support the hypothesis that repeated cycles of
allopatry may have been a major force promoting speciation in eastern
Asia, resulting in a greater species richness in the region compared to
eastern North America. The present research adds a new group to the few
examples of Out-of-America migration.
